00033 def default_property(name, allow_set=True, doc=None):
00034     """
00035     Creates the get/set properties for the given name.  It assumes that the
00036     actual attribute is '_' + name
00037 
00038     TODO: Expand this with domain validation to ensure the values are correct.
00039     """
00040     attribute_name = '_' + name
00041 
00042     def getter(self):
00043         return getattr(self, attribute_name)
00044 
00045     def setter(self, value):
00046         setattr(self, attribute_name, value)
00047 
00048     prop = property(getter, setter if allow_set else None, None, doc)
00049 
00050     def decorator(cls):
00051         setattr(cls, name, prop)
00052         return cls
00053 
00054     return decorator

00056 
00057 def common_urllib2_error_handler(exp):
00058 
00059     if isinstance(exp, urllib2.HTTPError):
00060         raise LsmError(ErrorNumber.PLUGIN_AUTH_FAILED, str(exp))
00061     if isinstance(exp, urllib2.URLError):
00062         desc = str(exp)
00063         if 'urlopen error' in desc:
00064             if 'Errno 111' in desc:
00065                 raise LsmError(ErrorNumber.NETWORK_CONNREFUSED,
00066                                'Connection refused')
00067             if 'Errno 113' in desc:
00068                 raise LsmError(ErrorNumber.NETWORK_HOSTDOWN,
00069                                'Host is down')
00070         error("Unexpected network error:\n" + traceback.format_exc())
00071         raise LsmError(ErrorNumber.NETWORK_ERROR, desc)
00072 
00073     stack_trace = traceback.format_exc()
00074     error("Unexpected exception:\n" + stack_trace)
00075     raise LsmError(ErrorNumber.PLUGIN_BUG, "Unexpected exception",
00076                    stack_trace)

00079 ## Documentation for Proxy class.
00080 #
00081 # Class to encapsulate the actual class we want to call.  When an attempt is
00082 # made to access an attribute that doesn't exist we will raise an LsmError
00083 # instead of the default keyError.
00084 class Proxy(object):
00085     """
00086     Used to provide an unambiguous error when a feature is not implemented.
00087     """
00088 
00089     ## The constructor.
00090     # @param    self    The object self
00091     # @param    obj     The object instance to wrap
00092     def __init__(self, obj=None):
00093         """
00094         Constructor which takes an object to wrap.
00095         """
00096         self.proxied_obj = obj
00097 
00098     ## Called each time an attribute is requested of the object
00099     # @param    self    The object self
00100     # @param    name    Name of the attribute being accessed
00101     # @return   The result of the method
00102     def __getattr__(self, name):
00103         """
00104         Called each time an attribute is requested of the object
00105         """
00106         if hasattr(self.proxied_obj, name):
00107             return functools.partial(self._present, name)
00108         else:
00109             raise LsmError(ErrorNumber.NO_SUPPORT,
00110                            "Unsupported operation")
00111 
00112     ## Method which is called to invoke the actual method of interest.
00113     # @param    self                The object self
00114     # @param    _proxy_method_name  Method to invoke
00115     # @param    args                Arguments
00116     # @param    kwargs              Keyword arguments
00117     # @return   The result of the method invocation
00118     def _present(self, _proxy_method_name, *args, **kwargs):
00119         """
00120         Method which is called to invoke the actual method of interest.
00121         """
00122         return getattr(self.proxied_obj, _proxy_method_name)(*args, **kwargs)
00123

00125 UDS_PATH = '/var/run/lsm/ipc'

00128 LOG_VERBOSE = True

00130 ##Constant for byte size
00131 SIZE_CONS = {
00132     'B': 1,
00133     'KiB': 2 ** 10,
00134     'KB': 10 ** 3,
00135     'K': 2 ** 10,
00136     'k': 2 ** 10,
00137     'MiB': 2 ** 20,
00138     'MB': 10 ** 6,
00139     'M': 2 ** 20,
00140     'm': 2 ** 20,
00141     'GiB': 2 ** 30,
00142     'GB': 10 ** 9,
00143     'G': 2 ** 30,
00144     'g': 2 ** 30,
00145     'TiB': 2 ** 40,
00146     'TB': 10 ** 12,
00147     'T': 2 ** 40,
00148     't': 2 ** 40,
00149     'PiB': 2 ** 50,
00150     'PB': 10 ** 15,
00151     'P': 2 ** 50,
00152     'p': 2 ** 50,
00153     'EiB': 2 ** 60,
00154     'EB': 10 ** 18,
00155     'E': 2 ** 60,
00156     'e': 2 ** 60,
00157 }
00158 SIZE_CONS_CHK_LST = ['EiB', 'PiB', 'TiB', 'GiB', 'MiB', 'KiB']
00159 
00160 
00161 ##Converts the size into human format.
00162 # @param    size    Size in bytes
00163 # @param    human   True|False
00164 # @return Human representation of size
00165 def sh(size, human=False):
00166     """
00167     Convert size in bytes to human readable size
00168     The return string will follow IEC binary prefixes, e.g. '1.9 KiB'
00169     For size less than 1024, we do nothing but return the int we get.
00170     TODO: Need a expect to handle when size is not a int. int() might do.
00171     """
00172     units = None
00173 
00174     if human:
00175         for key_name in SIZE_CONS_CHK_LST:
00176             if size >= SIZE_CONS[key_name]:
00177                 size /= float(SIZE_CONS[key_name])
00178                 units = key_name
00179                 break
00180         if not units:
00181             units = "B"
00182         return "%.2f %s" % (size, units)
00183     else:
00184         return size
00185 
00186 
00187 ##Converts the size into human format.
00188 # @param  size    Size in bytes
00189 # @return Human representation of size in IEC binary size prefixes.
00190 def size_bytes_2_size_human(size):
00191     """
00192     Convert integer size in bytes to human readable size.
00193     We are following rules of IEC binary prefixes on size:
00194         http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibibyte
00195     The biggest of unit this function supported is PiB.
00196     The precision is 2 which means you will get '1.99 KiB'
00197     """
00198     return sh(size, True)
00199 
00200 
00201 ##Converts the size into human format.
00202 # @param size_human Human readable size string, e.g. '1.9 KiB'
00203 # @return Size in bytes
00204 def size_human_2_size_bytes(size_human):
00205     """
00206     Convert human readable size string into integer size in bytes.
00207     Following rules of IEC binary prefixes on size:
00208         http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibibyte
00209     Supported input size_human in these formats:
00210         '1.9KiB'        # int(1024*1.9)
00211         '1 KiB'         # 2**10
00212         '1B'            # 1
00213         '2K'            # 2*(2**10), treated as '2KiB'
00214         '2k'            # 2*(2**10), treated as '2KiB'
00215         '2KB'           # 2*(10**3)
00216     """
00217     regex_size_human = re.compile(r"""
00218         ^
00219         ([0-9\.]+)          # 1: number
00220         [ \t]*              # might have space between number and unit
00221         ([a-zA-Z]*)         # 2: units
00222         $
00223     """, re.X)
00224     regex_match = regex_size_human.match(size_human)
00225     units = ''
00226     number = 0
00227     size_bytes = 0
00228     if regex_match:
00229         number = regex_match.group(1)
00230         units = regex_match.group(2)
00231         if not units:
00232             return int(number)
00233         units = units.upper()
00234         units = units.replace('IB', 'iB')
00235         if units in SIZE_CONS:
00236             size_bytes = SIZE_CONS[units] * float(number)
00237     return int(size_bytes)

00240 ## Common method used to parse a URI.
00241 # @param    uri         The uri to parse
00242 # @param    requires    Optional list of keys that must be present in output
00243 # @param    required_params Optional list of required parameters that
00244 #           must be present.
00245 # @return   A hash of the parsed values.
00246 def uri_parse(uri, requires=None, required_params=None):
00247     """
00248     Common uri parse method that optionally can check for what is needed
00249     before returning successfully.
00250     """
00251 
00252     rc = {}
00253     u = urlparse.urlparse(uri)
00254 
00255     if u.scheme:
00256         rc['scheme'] = u.scheme
00257 
00258     if u.netloc:
00259         rc['netloc'] = u.netloc
00260 
00261     if u.port:
00262         rc['port'] = u.port
00263 
00264     if u.hostname:
00265         rc['host'] = u.hostname
00266 
00267     if u.username:
00268         rc['username'] = u.username
00269     else:
00270         rc['username'] = None
00271 
00272     rc['parameters'] = uri_parameters(u)
00273 
00274     if requires:
00275         for r in requires:
00276             if r not in rc:
00277                 raise LsmError(ErrorNumber.PLUGIN_BUG,
00278                                'uri missing \"%s\" or is in invalid form' % r)
00279 
00280     if required_params:
00281         for r in required_params:
00282             if r not in rc['parameters']:
00283                 raise LsmError(ErrorNumber.PLUGIN_BUG,
00284                                'uri missing query parameter %s' % r)
00285     return rc
00286 
00287 
00288 ## Parses the parameters (Query string) of the URI
00289 # @param    uri     Full uri
00290 # @returns  hash of the query string parameters.
00291 def uri_parameters(uri):
00292     # workaround for python bug:
00293     # http://bugs.python.org/issue9374
00294     # for URL: smispy+ssl://admin@emc-smi:5989?namespace=root/emc
00295     # Before the patch commited( RHEL 6 and Fedora 18- ):
00296     #       '?namespace=root/emc' is saved in uri.path
00297     # After patched(RHEL 7 and Fedora 19+):
00298     #       'namespace=root/emc' is saved in uri.query
00299     query = ''
00300     if uri.query:
00301         query = uri.query
00302     elif uri.path:
00303         query = urlparse.urlparse('http:' + uri[2]).query
00304     else:
00305         return {}
00306     if query:
00307         return dict([part.split('=') for part in query.split('&')])
00308     else:
00309         return {}
00310

00312 ## Generates the md5 hex digest of passed in parameter.
00313 # @param    t   Item to generate signature on.
00314 # @returns  md5 hex digest.
00315 def md5(t):
00316     h = hashlib.md5()
00317     h.update(t)
00318     return h.hexdigest()

00321 ## Converts a list of arguments to string.
00322 # @param    args    Args to join
00323 # @return string of arguments joined together.
00324 def params_to_string(*args):
00325     return ''.join([str(e) for e in args])
00326 
00327 # Unfortunately the process name remains as 'python' so we are using argv[0] in
00328 # the output to allow us to determine which python exe is indeed logging to
00329 # syslog.
00330 # TODO:  On newer versions of python this is no longer true, need to fix.

00333 ## Posts a message to the syslogger.
00334 # @param    level   Logging level
00335 # @param    prg     Program name
00336 # @param    msg     Message to log.
00337 def post_msg(level, prg, msg):
00338     """
00339     If a message includes new lines we will create multiple syslog
00340     entries so that the message is readable.  Otherwise it isn't very readable.
00341     Hopefully we won't be logging much :-)
00342     """
00343     for l in msg.split('\n'):
00344         if len(l):
00345             syslog.syslog(level, prg + ": " + l)
00346 
00347 
00348 def error(*msg):
00349     post_msg(syslog.LOG_ERR, os.path.basename(sys.argv[0]),
00350              params_to_string(*msg))
00351 
00352 
00353 def info(*msg):
00354     if LOG_VERBOSE:
00355         post_msg(syslog.LOG_INFO, os.path.basename(sys.argv[0]),
00356                  params_to_string(*msg))

00366 @default_property('code', 'Error code')
00367 @default_property('msg', 'Error message')
00368 @default_property('data', 'Optional error data')
00369 class LsmError(Exception):
00370     def __init__(self, code, message, data=None, *args, **kwargs):
00371         """
00372         Class represents an error.
00373         """
00374         Exception.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
00375         self._code = code
00376         self._msg = message
00377         self._data = data
00378 
00379     def __str__(self):
00380         error_no_str = ErrorNumber.error_number_to_str(self.code)
00381         if self.data is not None and self.data:
00382             return "%s: %s Data: %s" % \
00383                    (error_no_str, self.msg, self.data)
00384         else:
00385             return "%s: %s " % (error_no_str, self.msg)
00386

00388 def addl_error_data(domain, level, exception, debug=None, debug_data=None):
00389     """
00390     Used for gathering additional information about an error.
00391     """
00392     return {'domain': domain, 'level': level, 'exception': exception,
00393             'debug': debug, 'debug_data': debug_data}

00396 def get_class(class_name):
00397     """
00398     Given a class name it returns the class, caller will then
00399     need to run the constructor to create.
00400     """
00401     parts = class_name.split('.')
00402     module = ".".join(parts[:-1])
00403     if len(module):
00404         m = __import__(module)
00405         for comp in parts[1:]:
00406             m = getattr(m, comp)
00407     else:
00408         m = __import__('__main__')
00409         m = getattr(m, class_name)
00410     return m

00413 #Note: Some of these don't make sense for python, but they do for other
00414 #Languages so we will be keeping them consistent even though we won't be
00415 #using them.
00416 class ErrorNumber(object):
00417     OK = 0
00418     LIB_BUG = 1
00419     PLUGIN_BUG = 2
00420     JOB_STARTED = 7
00421     TIMEOUT = 11
00422     DAEMON_NOT_RUNNING = 12
00423 
00424     NAME_CONFLICT = 50
00425     EXISTS_INITIATOR = 52
00426 
00427     INVALID_ARGUMENT = 101
00428 
00429     NO_STATE_CHANGE = 125
00430 
00431     NETWORK_CONNREFUSED = 140   # Host on network, but connection refused
00432     NETWORK_HOSTDOWN = 141      # Host unreachable on network
00433     NETWORK_ERROR = 142         # Generic network error
00434 
00435     NO_MEMORY = 152
00436     NO_SUPPORT = 153
00437 
00438     # Deletion related errors
00439     IS_MASKED = 160             # Volume is masked to access group.
00440 
00441     NOT_FOUND_ACCESS_GROUP = 200
00442     NOT_FOUND_FS = 201
00443     NOT_FOUND_JOB = 202

00457     PLUGIN_IPC_FAIL = 301       # Inter-process communication between client &
00458                                 # out of process plug-in encountered connection
00459                                 # errors.
00460

00462                                     # socket used for IPC

00472     # refuse to remove the last initiator from access group

00475

00477                                 # has no member/initiator.

00479     POOL_NOT_READY = 512        # Pool is not ready for create/resize/etc
00480 
00481     DISK_NOT_FREE = 513     # Disk is not in DISK.STATUS_FREE status.
00482 
00483     _LOCALS = locals()
00484 
00485     @staticmethod
00486     def error_number_to_str(error_no):
00487         for error_str in ErrorNumber._LOCALS.keys():
00488             if ErrorNumber._LOCALS[error_str] == error_no:
00489                 return "%s(%d)" % (error_str, error_no)
00490         return "UNKNOWN_ERROR_NUMBER(%d)" % error_no

00499 def type_compare(method_name, exp_type, act_val):
00500     if isinstance(exp_type, collections.Sequence):
00501         if not isinstance(act_val, collections.Sequence):
00502             raise TypeError("%s call is returning a %s, but is "
00503                             "expecting a sequence" %
00504                             (method_name, str(type(act_val))))
00505         # If the list has only one expected value we will make sure all
00506         # elements in the list adhere to it, otherwise we will enforce a one
00507         # to one check against the expected types.
00508         if len(exp_type) == 1:
00509             for av in act_val:
00510                 type_compare(method_name, exp_type[0], av)
00511         else:
00512             # Expect a 1-1 type match, extras get ignored at the moment
00513             for exp, act in zip(exp_type, act_val):
00514                 type_compare(method_name, exp, act)
00515     else:
00516         # A number of times a method will return None or some valid type,
00517         # only check on the type if the value is not None
00518         if exp_type != type(act_val) and act_val is not None:
00519             if (exp_type == unicode and type(act_val) == str):
00520                 return
00521             if not inspect.isclass(exp_type) or \
00522                     not issubclass(type(act_val), exp_type):
00523                 raise TypeError('%s call expected: %s got: %s ' %
00524                                 (method_name, str(exp_type),
00525                                  str(type(act_val))))
00526 
00527 
00528 def return_requires(*types):
00529     """
00530     Decorator function that allows us to ensure that we are getting the
00531     correct types back from a function/method call.
00532 
00533     Note: This is normally frowned upon by the python community, but this API
00534     needs to be language agnostic, so making sure we have the correct types
00535     is quite important.
00536     """
00537     def outer(func):
00538         @functools.wraps(func)
00539         def inner(*args, **kwargs):
00540             r = func(*args, **kwargs)
00541 
00542             # In this case the user did something like
00543             # @return_requires(int, string, int)
00544             # in this case we require that all the args are present.
00545             if len(types) > 1:
00546                 if len(r) != len(types):
00547                         raise TypeError("%s call expected %d "
00548                                         "return values, actual = %d" %
00549                                         (func.__name__, len(types), len(r)))
00550 
00551                 type_compare(func.__name__, types, r)
00552             elif len(types) == 1:
00553                 # We have one return type (but it could be a sequence)
00554                 type_compare(func.__name__, types[0], r)
00555 
00556             return r
00557         return inner
00558     return outer
00559

00561 class TestCommon(unittest.TestCase):
00562     def setUp(self):
00563         pass
00564 
00565     def test_simple(self):
00566 
00567         try:
00568             raise SocketEOF()
00569         except SocketEOF as e:
00570             self.assertTrue(isinstance(e, SocketEOF))
00571 
00572         try:
00573             raise LsmError(10, 'Message', 'Data')
00574         except LsmError as e:
00575             self.assertTrue(e.code == 10 and e.msg == 'Message' and
00576                             e.data == 'Data')
00577 
00578         ed = addl_error_data('domain', 'level', 'exception', 'debug',
00579                              'debug_data')
00580         self.assertTrue(ed['domain'] == 'domain' and ed['level'] == 'level'
00581                         and ed['debug'] == 'debug'
00582                         and ed['exception'] == 'exception'
00583                         and ed['debug_data'] == 'debug_data')
00584 
00585     def tearDown(self):
00586         pass

00590     unittest.main()
